content.description: Start same as Up Yours Direct move out and left to the high arete and up.  The holds get really thin after the first couple moves getting matched into a crescent shaped hold midway up.
Start on either side of the wall traversing to the other end using the high line of jugs.
Start on either end of the wall traversing and staying below the 6' mark or so.  Good warm up area and usually the driest spot in the park.
Low start on the right side of the Yellow Wall and climb to the large obvious shelf about 12' up and drop.
Start on good edges at the six foot level and go all the way up the the large ledge about 12' up.  Going to the lower ledge is called the Jaundice Jump.

Sit start on low holds on the far right side if the Yellow Wall.  Move up and slightly right staying on the arete and off the large holds around the corner.  Drop once you get into choss or go for the top and cross your fingers.
Same start as Wheeties except move left into the good pocket on the orange streak and then up.  Solid problem, super bad angled landing makes it rarely climbed.

Start left of Homeostasis with your left hand on 3 pad flat hold, right hand on a two finger micro edge, climb straight up to a few edges and finish on the large seam.  This is one of the older boulder problems at the park and has stood the test of time over the years often overlooked and shied away from.  The rock is solid and although a shorter problem provides many ways for a send.
content.location: Between the two Orange streaks on the face on the Eastern most side of the cliff.

content.description: Same as WG Cundey Eliminate but continue right one more move into a small edge under the feature and then go straight up finishing on good edges 10 feet up and drop.  The large feature used for the route proper is still off.
Sit start on low block left of the proper route.  Traverse right through thin edges, eliminate the large feature out right, and go straight up to gain a stance.

Start just down from Thailand and just before Saving Grace.  Sit start on the large jug shelf and climb up the two featured arete and drop at a high point before getting into the choss.  Notice the carving next to it and the origin of the problems name.

Same start as Two Peace

but move straight up after the first move eventually gaining opposing side pulls and up into the crimp.  Move out left into the jug shelf and call it good or top out which is way more fun.This is an old climb rated 5.11+ in a guidebook that went out of existence around 2000 and has been pretty much abandoned until recently.

Start on the obvious shelf under the roof at the left side of the great roof.  Climb staight out and then left gaining a stance on the face.  Call it good or TR to the top with 5.9 climbing, much better broulder problem than TR.
content.location: Across from the Tooth under the left side of the roof on obvious shelf.

content.description: Start at the crack, move along pockets and decent feet until you're under the V and can reach up to top out. A long reach and effective edging help.
content.protection: 1 crash pad for the last move
content.location: One of the first problems you'll find after walking down the stairs

content.description: Start left of Doug's Roof on low jug and left sidepull.  Climb straight up heading for the slot at the top of the face, up and left of the "Up Yours" mono and end there.  Kind of a high fall from the top but the landing is good.
Sit start on low holds under the black overlap. Stay right of the rounded arête, climb to the jugs or contend with the filthy top out for bonus points.
content.location: On the "Bouldering Wall" climber's left of the "Slag Traverse"

content.description: Sit start on the rock in front of the sun and up through the the large crack
content.location: Look for the sun on the wall. Mid way through the crag.

content.description: Start in the large obvious pocket up in the corner left of the Mermaid Carving.  Traverse right to the large crack dividing the wall and then up, go as far as you want as the crack is usually pretty muddy and a mess.

Start between the mermaid carving and rock pedestal in the corner on a good ledge.  Climb up on thin edges, use the mermaid with a right hand and get into the obvious pockets and up.  There is a good ledge below the top (marked in orange on one of the pics), call it good here and drop or go for the top out.This is basically the lighter version of Peace with an easier start and end.  Although they overlap in the middle the climbs are quite different as simply pulling up on Peace may be the crux.

Start on the face with both hands at chest height, then get the half moon shaped hold. Eventually, get on the right arete and fire to the obvious finishing ledge and drop off.This can be topped out or top roped to the top but it is not recommended it is loose and dirty and not as fun as the lower section.
content.location: Walk West past most of the top roping, the trick is located just left of poison ivy jam and just to the right of a two foot tall "9" or backward "P" etched in the wall. You should see the chalk.

content.description: Get into the a set of holds around 6' up and launch for the top.
Same start as the Trick, eliminate the arete and climb straight up using a small edge high and right.

Start just below of The Trick on a low and obvious block.  Climb the face without using the large crack sticking to the arete and some edges.There is a large and intimidating looking rock behind this climb but it doesn't really come into play.  The lower part of the climb falls come straight down and as you get higher the tendency is to drift left and the rock is not really close to the drop zone.
Start on low obvious block and climb the arete only.  There's the jug low and a small micro edge about 3/4 of the way up the arete.  Finish on the large ledge system same as Trick and Treat.
Start a few feet left of Mini Crack, grab an edge at chest level and shoot for the top block slightly left.
Sit start with both hands as low as you can go with your left heel hooked and placed in a slight depression. Continue up the arete and top out at the end. A great little warm up.
content.protection: one pad, there is a boulder right off the start that could really hurt your tail bone.
content.location: Locate the large pile of rocks that have obviously fallen of the cliff. The largest boulder is the tooth boulder.  It is opposite Ludwig's dude and Resistance.

content.description: Just like it sounds, sit start on the right of the tooth and climb the short arete with a nice top out.

Start a couple feet left of Max Scene Arete on good lower block.  Climb up the arete eliminating all the large holds out left leaving you a couple small edges and a useful knob.  End in the triangle hold and drop or top out.
Start same as Ballerina and traverse right through some very funky moves.  Finish matched on the good rail just left of Up Yours Direct start.
Start on low block and climb up and left eliminating both arete features to a couple good holds and drop.
Long black streak of rock, climber's left of "Saving Grace." Standard traverse is left to right.

Start is to the right of Highball and four feet left of Top Tier Dyno.  Start on a sharp right crimp and bad left hand.  Go straight up and top out.  Several variations of this exist as well, all around the same level of difficulty.
Start same as Scofic, move left hand up, right onto a bad edge, left up onto a bad sloper and shoot for a good hold.  I don't think this has ever been done and is still a project at the park.

Start left of the “SAVING GRACE 8/5/27”   engraving on the overhanging slopey bulge.

Start on the jug 4’ left and below the engraving and climb up into the   faint water groove avoiding the huge ledges to the rightStart left of the “SAVING GRACE 8/5/27” engraving on the overhanging slopey bulge. Start on the jug 4’ left and below the engraving and climb up into the faint water groove avoiding the huge ledges to the right.
content.location: Start left of the “SAVING GRACE 8/5/27” engraving.

content.description: Start on Saving Grace starter block and dyno to the good rail above, match and top out.

Start on Rocket Man and traverse right around the corner, across Despondency and onto the pillar in the corner.  Traversing either way is about the same difficulty but offers a different sets of moves.
Low start matched on an iron plate and traverse left staying low until you end on the start hold of Intimidator.

Start left of Ludwig's Dude on small pockets.  Move up and right into the slash, grab the bad side pull with left and jump to finish on the ledge.  Top rope to finish to the top.  Jamie Emerson first finished this is in 2000 and it stood as the hardest problem in the park until recently with Dylan Bark's V10 D-Bag.3 Pads minimum.

Start left of the arete and just left of the "9" carved into the rock above.  Climb up through crimps into seem and up into the backwards "P" carving finishing on the ledge.  This is the highest boulder problem and is typically done on a rope.  Topping out onto the ledge is easy enough but there is still some choss to be climbed after that to get all the way on top and a fall could easily be lethal.

This is a low traverse that slowly gets a bit higher as you work your way further to the left. It has a technical crux of hand holds that are hard to see, as well as an endurance crux.

 Unlike many of the established climbs like Potato Chips and Dougs Roof where climbers have excavated the top soil to for setting anchors, this climb has dirt all along the top of the cliff so it is in constant need of brushing each day you attempt it. The feet, the hands, it all needs brushed... every single hold gets very sandy.

 Be careful about potential ankle breaker on the rail road tie.
content.location: Start about 8 feet right of the big long flat rail...Find a slopey sidepull for your right hand and a three finger flat edge for your left hand, right into a big slot and match in there then work your way over to the big long rail where people put their feet on three mules...Stay low with your hands on that long rail instead of your feet traversing over with some smears for your feet until you get to better feet with some good hidden edges.  Keep going all the way over into the pockets for The Pretzel where this climb ends.  Match with both hands on the final pocket to the left.

content.description: Start right hand in the pocket and left hand on a pinch/edge in the roof and shoot up and left into the hueco then top out.

Start down and right from the carving at a chest high ledge.  Move p and angled right into the top of the carving and match in the hold created my her high hand and drop or top out.  This is another of GL's older lines, the railroad ties make it a tough landing cruxing out directly over them.
Start just right of the crack and climb straight up thru small edges in the obvious large seam.  Crack to the left is off and go straight up.
Start on a decent left facing side-pull and crank with the right to a hold just over the mini roof. Find a foot and launch to the jug up and left. Top out.
content.location: Number 47 "Unknown F" in the Fixed Pin guidebook. 5 feet left of Ballerina

content.description: Start a couple of feet left of Asinine Behavior on opposing sidepulls. Further up, finish in a thinner part of the same ledge system or a smaller rail a few feet below.   There is a low start on some sidepulls and moving into the original start holds.   This climbs up and into a two-finger pocket eventually meeting up with Pretzel proper.  The landing is usually really muddy though and on a slope.
Start right of Pretzel on some side pulls for a low start or a couple not so good holds higher up.  Climb up and trending left into into original problem.

***Watch out for the railroad tie, it is an ankle buster****

 Dave Poxson had the idea to extend this regular traverse into one that tops out.  Climb almost all of Coffee Talk and then work your way into Highball/The Pocket Problem

Start on the ground just left of the rock pedestal that Pigeon Shit starts on.  Left hand in small pocket and right in sidepull crack and make your way up and slightly left into jug and the rope route.

Start on the large and obvious slopey ledge.  Traverse right only using holds on the seam at the same height of starting hold.  Eventually get the feet in the letters and move into another obvious block above the seam, gain a stance on this block and call it good or top out exiting left.

Start on a bad left crimp and a smaller right edge and throw out right to a decent side pull.  Climb straight up and into the right most part of the mermaid carving, then into the right of the two obvious small pockets and up.  Gear up for one final big move into a jug a few feet below the lip.  Top out or drop high from the jugs, may as well top out from this point.Traversing left or right is not part of this problem as there are lines next to this one and that will get you into easier climbing.  Getting off the ground can be tricky as this is the hardest start at the park.  The line goes straight up to an alright top out, although a bit high.The development of this problem took a winding road as the initial pursuit was to find Wall Street which was last mentioned in a guide published in the 90's from Trails Edge that went at 5.11+.  Two Peace was the result of the initial pursuit and then rediscovering Wall Street to the left

followed.  The thin slot to start Peace was then established with its own top out coming next resulting in this line that stands on its own without any eliminates that is sustained the entire climb.

Grand Ledge eliminate.  Sit start on two low/thin edges.  Climb up into the sloper, the jug part of it is off, and then up and left into the large ledge and drop.  The large ledge off left at the start is also off.  The start holds are directly below the start of Rocket man and a foot is straight down and low.

Great little slab to practice balance on. The intended way to climb it is without using elbows, arms, or knees to aid you in climbing this slabby rock. Great fun to try out just for kicks. It unfortunately doesn't help warm up your hands for other climbing.
content.protection: Keep your hands ready to stabilize if you do slip. A crash pad and spotter highly recommended so that you do not slide and roll right down the hill and into the river.
content.location: Far left side of the crag, on the side of the path opposite of the wall.

content.description:
Low start to Shorty A Comp Style Problem

 Start on a flat undercling and a low rail...hand foot match the rail then finish on Shorty..

 Has two cruxes, the start, and the finish (depending on your reach)

Start on a low shelf on the right side of the wall.  Climb up and out into the large hold on the arete.  Finish and drop, gain a stance or go for a dirty top out.An old eliminate was removing the hold circled in green, Mr. Sulu, about the same grade.
Low start matched on a large iron plate and move up the face into the obvious seam and drop.  The large ledge out right is off.
Sit start in short vertical crack on right side of the wall.  Straight up and top out for a nice warm up.

This is an older problem and has changed over the years because of erosion and how much lower the ground is now on the west side of the great roof.Start/finish on the Walk on By starter block and the right most set of holds on the wall before the corner to the Mermaid Wall.
content.location: Overhang Between blind faith and right corner before the Nose area

content.description: Start same as Mass Hysteria traversing left.  Instead of moving up into A Comedy of Terrors Direct, continue traversing into Ballerina and top out.This is reversing the Suicide Machine line that Jamie Emerson established in 2000 or so.  Locals looked at this for years afterwards with no success.  When Brendan Baars came along he not only finally did the long-standing project reversing the traverse, he added the hardest line to top it out creating Mass Hysteria which is an amazing line...some of us just ain't that strong!

Start on low opposing side pulls down in the carved letters below and right of the Mermaid carving.  Move into delicate climbing left and up, avoiding all the lower holds on Rated-X until joining the problem proper higher up on the carving.  Climb straight up the carving and finish on pockets above the carving or top out.The three holds that wind up off are the start hold for Rated X, the large ledge above that block and then the large sidepull out right.

Start on the low block and move into a thin edge with the right hand.  Work out left staying on the face and finishing in the large triangle feature or top out a few more feet of easier climbing.  The large ledges out right and good pocket are off as this stays on the left of the face and going right is an old climb named Staircase done on TR.

Tricky intro into Comedy of Terrors Direct. Start with hands in the jug part of a decent left facing vertical slash and traverse left until you can gain the good crimp under the roof below the Comedy of Terrors Direct headwall.
content.protection: 3-4 pads, spotter; perhaps a spotter for your spotter
content.location: Starts 10 feet right of Comedy of Terrors/Ballerina

content.description: Sit start and climb up and pull the left side of the small roof.  Top out and walk around on the stairs.
content.location: 50' right of the Buns Bulge near the west stairs.

content.description: Eliminate - Same start as the Mantle Problem, eliminate all holds on the sides of the roof and go straight out instead of finishing up and left.
Start on the Intimidator block and climb right through edges finishing on Cowabunga Direct.
Start on the two obvious crimps and smear up the slab. Nice topout and an easy exit on the backside.
content.location: Around the left of the overhanging roof. About 30 yards from the west stairs.

content.description: Hand to foot and up the slab. Requires adult assist or the pre-pubescent amygdala of Alex Honnold.

Start on two small stacked two edges left and below the Intimidator Block on the lip.  High left heel on the larger step or right heel on a small/good edge and climb into the traditional start for the route and gain a stance.  Contrived but its alright.
Same start as Enigma and get into the left side pull and cross over into the slash on Heart and Soul, then up into the finishing large pocket.
Start eight feet left of Finesse on high starter block and end matched on the same ledge system as Finesse.

Start just left of Despondency, climbing up/left out to the arête before topping out well off the deck.  This climb is rarely bouldered as opposed to top rope, as it is high, but has some of the best rock and better moves at Oak Park.  This is the second highest problem at the park only behind V8 Reflections and both have potential serious consequences from a fall up high where the crux's are.
Start just left of Anastasis with a high left side pull and a small carbonite pocket.  Move up and into the good edge and then into the high pocket and end in the seam.

Start high on the carbinite jug on Walk on By, climb up and right along the lip of the roof into a big jug.  Go straight up from the gaining a stance on the jug and jump down.  this can obviously be linked to the end of V4 Walk on By for a full value pump.
Large pockets, easy boulder. Great warm up.
content.location: Far right side of the crag, easy to spot big holds on a blank face.

content.description: Best Dyno at the park.  Left hand on a decent sidepull and right on an edge, paste your feet and go out right to a big slash.  Match and call it good, gain the face or top out into dirt.
content.location: 6 feet left of Enigma on the Mermaid Wall.

content.description: Same as Grady but eliminate the high ledge system, staying on the lower holds, topping out same as Grady.

Sit start on the right side of the bulge about 15’ left of the diving board/mantle problem. There is a fist sized crack about 3’ in length below chest level that serves as the start. Eliminate the large diagonal crack near the start and everything above the obvious ledge system traversing it across to the left and topping it out when it peters out.
content.location: On the Buns Bulge just a few feet down from the western staircase.

content.description: Sit start on low edges on the left center of Midget's Wall.  Climb straight up and into the hold onto the roof and drop.

Park eliminate but a fun one one you establish what's on.Same start as Ride or Die on the iron plate and climb into the hatchet hold in the roof used on Rocket Man.  Take off the large ledge at eight feet left of Rocket Man, the good hold above the big sloper, and the starting holds to Rocket Man.

climbs.name: Fred T. GILLEMS MILLINERY AND DRY GOODS

content.description:
Start out by climbing half way up the crack to Poison Ivy Jam and then follow the thin crack seam (about 10 feet up) to the left under the old painted advertisement that reads "Fred T. GILLEMS MILLINERY AND DRY GOODS"

 Make your way over to the other pedestal that Dave wants to remove

This is the boulder problem to Frank's Climb which goes to the top.Start with left in shallow pocket and right on thin crimp.  Move up into a really small pocket and a decent crimp and go for the seam.  Continue to the top on TR or drop from the seam.
Start matched on a ledge at chest level, eight feet left of Highball.  Mantle onto the ledge, stand up, and call it good.

Start on good edge next to Intimidator Direct, traverse low on the lip and right into the Cowabunga pocket and good edge finish.This is a fairly old GL eliminate on the lowest line possible, that went unsent for many years, until Dylan came along.
Climb the arete and exit stage left.
content.location: On the west side of the crag about 50 yards from the west stairs.

content.description: Start with a right hand side-pull on the right side of the arete at chest height and your left on a side-pull in some carbonate deposit hold. Step your left foot anywhere you can get a clean foot and match your right heel to your right hand and go. The problem ends at the very large side-pull in the shield hold.  Low start on opposing side pull right below the traditional start.  Tends to be set in the super but dry in the off seasons.  Its a good start to a great problem and not adding to the grade but it does get you full points on the problem.
content.location: As you walk down the East path to the river and bottom of the cliff, it is the first arete you come to. You can't miss it.

content.description: Same as the mantle but on the right side instead
content.location: Coming from the stairs just past buns machine

content.description: Start same as Grady.  Climb through the large diagonal crack above the Grady line and top out in the middle of the bulge right of Grady.
Start right at the waist-high ledge at the base of the pedestal and go straight up and then left at the end to finish on the good ledge.

Despondency except the lower typical right-hand start hold, the slightly higher typical left-hand start hold and the thin chipped pocket above the crescent edge are all off as you boulder to the same ledge.  The theme is the three manufactured holds are off.
with your left hand in a slot, and your right hand on a nice flat edge, put your foot up high and jump up finding the jug on the left side of the long rail.
Start under the corner between Rocket Man and Despondency.  Climbing straight up on the arete finishing on a large edge or a high top out.
Go straight up while avoiding bailing out right.   This is one of the older lines that finishes with a top rope.  This problem has also been bouldered out, as have many of the rope climbs.
Same as midget’s delight just in reverse
Start left hand in seam and right hand under the roof on an edge.  Climb along the lip of the small roof finishing up on the arete gaining a stance on the face, same as Blind Faith.
Low start on the iron plate and climb up and slightly left into good holds under the small roof then through thin edges up to the obvious ledge or into the large seem.
Start on the left facing block as for Ballerina Direct and make a big move out right, continue trending up and left into the chossy headwall. Top out and downclimb Ballerina until you can drop off.
content.protection: 3-4 pads and a really good spotter, and maybe a spotter for your spotter.

content.description: Start at the base of the right side of the roof on jugs.  Climb out the arête a few feet and up to gain a stance and drop or top out.

Start at the side pull and crimp just below Ballerina (green tick marks shows start) Use slippery feet under you and crank up and right (red ticks shows holds). Crux is just over the lip, holding on to a sloper and throwing for a small crimp.
content.protection: A pad or two, spotter is always nice.
content.location: Route is between Doug's roof and potato chips. After topping down climb potato chips to get down.

content.description: Start on the Walk on By block and traverse right through Midget’s Delight and around the corner, ending on the Nose.  The low rocks on the ground at the end of the traverse are off for full value.
Start in the corner and move up and right topping out on the bulge.  Was much safer before the wooden pedestal for ropers was added...

***Be careful of the Railroad Tie, it is a a potential ankle buster****

 Start on the pretzel and climb to the right finishing on a low slopey sidepull...This climbs Rathke's Traverse except it goes to the right. For more of a description, just basically do the opposite of what it says to do on Rathke's Traverse ending on the low three finger edge and the slopey sidepull. 

 The crux is at the deep round hole for most people. Depending on the season and what the weather has been doing the feet at the beginning are sometimes completely dry, or completely wet.
content.location: Start a few different ways on The Pretzel, just work your way up into the three finger pocket and start on your way over to the right.

content.description: Same as ride or die just in reverse
Start 4' left of Saving Grace and a little lower in a large undercling pocket.  Climb straight up topping out on the Saving Grace Bulge.
Start at the left of the large crack in the Buns Bulge.  Climb right and when the crack ends top it out.

Start as far back left on the bulge as you can with two slopey edges.  Throw up a heel and climb into Buns Machine Gun proper.  Instead of toping out after the large pocket stay low and continue right into the large triangle shaped pocket.  Move up staying off all the good edges used on Buns Machine Gun toping out on the arete.

Eliminate - Start on the left of the Buns Bulge low below the obvious ledge bisecting the bulge.  Start hold has hands stacked below eliminated ledge climbing on the lower set of holds into a deep/good pocket then top out same as Buns Machine Gun High.A rock broke sometime in 2020 creating another good hold on the line making it somewhat softer than the V5 assigned but it's still a good problem with a solid top out.

On the left side of the Buns Bulge on the huge ledges the obvious start.  Paste the feet somewhere underneath and jump for the top.  Going out left to the lower ledge or using any other starting holds other than the ledge itself is not part of the problem, although they're still fun.
Links suicide machine(v6) to up yours direct (v5) feels close to as hard as mass hysteria light.
content.location: Start same as ballerina, and traverse left into up yours direct.

content.description: Stand start on the corner with left pocket and good right edge.  Left hand up to the softball sized sloper and then move onto the face finishing in the large seam.

Same start as Walk on By.  After the first couple of moves, go up into a crimp and out onto the arete finishing in the crescent moon.  The Walk on By jug is off as the problem climbs the arete straight up.
content.location: Left side of the Great Roof

content.description: Another eliminate on the Ballerina Bulge but it's a decent one.  Same start as Ballerina, and as the name suggests you only use the holds on the right of the open book and holds beneath.  The corner is on as the steepness lacks other holds, but the ledge for Ballerina proper and everything above is definitely off.
Eliminate - Start same as Ballerina High and eliminate everything on the right side of the book and top out.

Stack pads, use stump, or jump start to a two hand rail, pull through the open book, walk over to chips and climb down. Could be a bad fall on the retaining wall be careful. A dirty and wet direct start begins awkwardly a bit lower on a two handed undercling/sidepull, and goes at V5
content.location: Between the main overhang area and "chips", at the retaining wall

content.description: Start to the right and under the main bulge of the park, just left of Doug's Roof.  This is the Ballerina bulge and holds some of the best problmes at the park.  Start low on right edge and left on the sidepull.  Climb straight up, move over left into the book and finish with a top out.  Ballerina High starts after the crux of the low problem and is much easier.

A traverse that starts/ends on Rocket Man and Inappropriate Behavior.  Climb up about 8' and work your way through the large ledge used on Astral Traverse.  There is an eliminate that takes the large ledge off called Minus One Traverse that goes around V5.
Same as the rope climb but with pads.  Start right of Rocket Man on a large positive hold, move up to a large edge and then a big move up and left into another large ledge and drop.

Start just left of Intergalactic Quaalude Trip on a high right diagonal good hold and reach out left for a less than ideal hold.  Climb up and slight left and go into the left part of the obvious seam and drop.

Start just down and left from the Cowabunga Direct start with a small left edge and a bad right slopey edge.  Move right into the Cowabunga Direct pocket and continue up/left without using any other holds from Cowabunga Direct to gain a stance matched on a good edge below the seam and drop or to the seam.This is a fairly old line at the park as it used to be done on TR and climbing to the top, much better boulder problem though.
Same start as Anastasis and climb up into good edges and instead of going left and into the pocket, stay slightly right and into the good higher hold on Heart and Soul and into the seam.
Same start as Heart and Soul Direct, on the side pull block left of Enigma.Climb up trending left though small edges into a higher slot and finish at the large obvious seam.

Grand Ledge is most known for its top rope routes; however, there is some quality bouldering to be had. If you are looking for solitude, the far left side of the cliff, which does not contain the popular top rope routes, has some fun bouldering. This side of the cliff tends to stay more in the shade and can remain damp after rain much longer. Bouldering in the center of cliff--from ballerina to Despondency--tends to be steeper and more powerful. This area also gets direct sunlight. As many of these problems intersect and share top rope climbs, be courteous. Below is a list of the projects, classics, better climbs and the sub areas within the park.  Although the band of rock is relatively small, there are distinct areas within it and is useful to understand their locations as the locals will refer to them by these names and its just easier to find the problem you are looking for.  The list starts on the East Wall which would be to the left walking out of the parking lot.*** See Map that is in the photo section for orientation to the problems.https://www.mountainproject.com/photo/121930624
